shawn.graham   (edited 2021-03-16 4:13 p.m.) 2020-03-02 2:55 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
Europeana API,

The thought occurs that we could do something akin to the 'data hubs' article. Imagine we were trying to build a 'digital museum of canada in the world'. Our 'museum' would be an API that exposes all of the materials held by all of the museums in the world that have 'canadian' things. We could do this, or at least begin to imagine this, like so -

  1. collective google doc with the urls to as many museum apis that we can find
  2. query these for 'Canada'
  3. download the results as csv files
  4. use the csvs-to-sqlite package to convert each csv into a db
  5. use datasette to publish one big api with several different tables
  6. ta da! profit and enjoy.... maybe we'll try this in class.
  7. build some infographics to visualize some of what we're finding.

Now, if we really were building all of this, we'd do all of this programmatically, but for right now, it's ok to do this kind of combination of code/manual work. This is a thought exercise.

here's a more complicated command, that I used to publish to heroku and to install the clustermap plugin while I was at it. I took this data https://github.com/RepoData/RepoData and turned it into a db, then published at http://repodata.herokuapp.com/

datasette publish heroku --name repodata data.db --about "RepoData for US Archives - Exploring the data from https://github.com/RepoData/RepoData with Datasette; data collected by the RepoData project team, 2017-2019, Ben Goldman, Eira Tansey, and Whitney Ray." --install=datasette-cluster-map

Ed Summers took the same data, and used the Leaflet API + the Google Streetview API to map it and provide you a view on the mapped street location https://repodata.github.io/RepoMap/

▶  3  Updating Your Devlogs | HIST4806A Museums + Digital History shawngraham.github.io

shawn.graham   (edited 2021-03-16 4:13 p.m.) 2020-02-24 3:37 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
Do not use : in your titles or metadata. The colon tells the computer that the previous word was a ‘key’ and then the next thing will be the value that describes the key. So if you have another colon in there - say, title: devlog1: it begins your site won’t build. If you must have a colon, then you have to wrap it in quotations, eg title: "devlog1: it begins".

I really can't emphasize this enough, as this seems to have tripped a number of you up.

dhmuse

shawn.graham   (edited 2021-03-16 4:13 p.m.) 2020-01-08 3:29 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
there are key:value pairs that describe the metadata.

Be careful here: the : tells the machine that everything to the left of the colon is a key, and everything to the right is a value. If you used a : in say the Name field, like so:

Name: Shawn's Page: The Adventure Begins!

the machine will throw an error, because it'll start looking for a key called 'page' to push through the template (eg, does the template use a key called page?) Since it won't find such a thing, it will throw an error and it won't update.

If you really really want to use a colon inside a value, you have to wrap it in quotes, like so:

Name: "Shawn's Page: The Adventure Begins!"

and that'll be ok.

dhmuse
shawn.graham   (edited 2021-03-16 4:13 p.m.) 2020-01-08 3:24 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
academic-kickstart/content/authors/admin

the link above of course goes nowhere, (for now; maybe someday John Smith will actually turn up on github)

shawn.graham   (edited 2021-03-16 4:13 p.m.) 2020-01-08 3:23 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
Resize it to about 100 pixels wide

You can do this using the 'preview' program on Mac, or in whatever the image/photo app is on a PC. Generally, there will be a 'tools' item in the menu or toolbar for the program, and then look for a 'resize' option. Note that sometimes the default units of meaurement might be in cms or inches; there should be a dropdown button allowing you to change this to pixels.

Then put in 100 , hit the resize or enter button, then save the image with a new name. ta da!

shawn.graham   (edited 2021-03-16 4:13 p.m.) 2020-01-09 3:06 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Looks to me like you've successfully built the site, but the reason your image might not be appearing is because it's either in the wrong spot, or there's an issue with the file name. Can you give me the link to your github account?

More about the difference between github and netlify: Github is a bucket into which you drop your content. Because you're writing simple text files, your stuff will always be future proof, and available for other uses.

Netlify is a free webhost. Normally, we would convert our text files into html to go on the web on our own computer, using software. But netlify also has that software built in, that engine. So we never have to worry about it.

We make changes to our content; netlify watches for those changes, and then pushes our content through some templates to turn it into html. It then hosts those html at http://chloe-dennis.netlify.com.

I've added some instructions at the bottom of this page on how to delete the green welcome bar.

dhmuse

▶  36  Why do we collect? archivaldecolonist.com

sianwilliams   2021-03-10 11:08 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
Regarding First Nations culture, people often state that one of the reasons why archives and museums collect First Nations cultural heritage is to preserve it from its inevitable historical decay or loss.

I think this is a really interesting statement. It almost implicitly expresses how if these artifacts and archives weren't gathered by Westernized institutions, they would therefore be inaccessible and 'lost'. I agree with the author's follow-up point, in which they state First Nations don't need help in preserving their culture - I would argue they need more outlets and branches in which they can express and display their culture properly for a global audience, as well as their own! Especially after reading Kate's annotations, it is abundantly clear that First Nations folk know how to preserve their own culture and do so in a way that is reflective of their beliefs and the meaning that follows these artifacts and archives, which is something they ultimately should have control over - which i think only expands when we consider digitized history and archives!

culture
representation
digitization
westernization

paulaarodrigo   2021-03-03 8:12 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

This argument reminds me of issues addressed in one of the articles that I annotated, "Non-Western Models of Museums and Curation in Cross-cultural Perspective." In that article, they go over the fact that many non-Western cultures have robust curation practices that originate from before Europeans colonized the world. I think that being knowledgeable of these practices and respecting traditional practices of object keeping and displaying could help to reframe the negative connotation that museums have for Indigenous communities and communities of colour.

kateredner   2021-02-23 7:46 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

In this article the author Nathan Sentance discusses multiple issues with collecting artifacts from other cultures. Some of the emotions that have emerged from the first nations people regarding their cultural artifacts, suggests that their artifacts have been misrepresented. Ownership on these artifacts is also addressed concerning how they should be displayed, and the context in which they are represented in. The risk of an artifact being de-contextualized a few years down the road is also discussed. When considering the fact that first nations history is taught and learned by touching these artifacts, a statement is also mentioned on how these artifacts can be misunderstood, due to their display behind glass cases. The lack of repatriated artifacts is also addressed. The feelings that arise from all of these issues causes the author to argue that museums are only intended to legitimize colonialization, while degrading the history of other cultures. The author concludes with the comment that museums need to change their perspective on how and what they preserve, and to think about if their preservation and display methods are causing more harm than good.

kbingham   2021-03-04 10:50 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Like paulaarodrigo said, perhaps it is better to preserve the artifact digitally and allow the culture they belong to decide what happens to them. By keeping a physical object, there is a sense of possession, of ownership, that is problematic with cultural objects. Taking a picture or 3d scan doesn’t take anything away from a culture and allows them to decide the physical object’s fate. In this way, the knowledge can be preserved and the culture respected. (assuming they are okay with the digitization, of course)

To put it in another context, there was a saying I was taught in Scouts about how to behave in nature, “Take only photographs, leave only footprints.” In order to best preserve nature, we need to leave it alone to change, grow, and decay as it is meant to. If we take a small tree out of the forest and plant it in a garden, we will not be preserving the forest. Taken away from the context, it belonged in a tree is just a tree. It will change separately from the forest and will never represent what a tree from that forest is like. The best way to preserve a forest when we visit it is not to take part of it away but to record what the forest was like then through other non-harmful methods like photos, videos, or etchings. I believe that representing other cultures in museums is similar. If one removes an artifact from its culture, it is forever altered by the new context in which it is found. The best way to preserve the knowledge represented by an artifact would be to capture information on it in its original context, ideally through digital methods and testimony. To sum up my point, once an artifact is taken, its nature changes. It is no longer an artifact representing a culture and instead becomes an artifact that was taken from a culture. To preserve remnants of history from cultures outside our own, we need to do so respectfully, either with consent and cooperation with the original cultures or by focusing on recoding knowledge instead of taking and possessing it.

preservation
Colonialism
⤷
kateredner   2021-03-05 7:25 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I definatley agree that having a digital version of the artifact would certainly be a better method of sharing cultural knowledge and traditions, while still allowing that culture to have their artifacts back. I suppose then the next step would be to ask that culture if they would be willing to allow us to go forward with this new method.

rysegaert   2021-02-21 11:25 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
The “preserve forever” mentality is very much based on Western idea of time being linear and irreversible (Smith, 2012, 64). It is also a colonial value judgment and is part of colonial institutions deciding what is and is not valuable now and in the future.

"Western idea of time being linear and irreversible"; Although this may feel to be a fact in the moment, the meaning of 'time' in this statement stresses the irreversible fear of determining value. The term "preserve forever" suggests that the only way for your preservation to have value is for it to still physically exists. That is the materialist colonial value of "preserve forever". On the other hand, First Nations don't see preservation practices being so linear, they respect preservation practices of living culture wherein 'time' and value are evaluated differently
⤷
JacobSpierings   2021-03-10 11:31 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

It is interesting to think about cultural differences in the context of preservation. European culture emphasizes the importance of material items in many aspects including preservation. Indigenous peoples tended to have an oral tradition and therefore does not seem to have this same emphasis on material items when it comes to remembering. Here we can see how European values are being prescribed to non-European topics.

rysegaert   2021-02-21 11:04 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

This article describes the process in regard to the archival and collections of First Nations culture. More importantly, the author seeks clarification; why we collect these artifacts and for what reason? The Western idea of ‘preserve forever’ considers time being linear and irreversible, thus enabling misinterpretation for the reason of collection and archive. Sentance argues, if a museum employee video records a First Nations dance, it is not necessarily preserving First Nations culture when these dances were taught and learnt over thousands of years. In turn, this short video clip does not meet the goal of preserving First Nations culture. Though the intention may be well, we see lots of First Nations cultural heritage archives not only in the wrong medium but in the wrong context in which they are preserved. Museums and archival institutions tend to ignore archival practices of living cultures to ensure their context. Whether that is behind glass or in storage, it is not preserving the context of this type. So, if First Nations cultural heritage is being preserved unnaturally and conflicts with their interests, who are archives and museums collection First Nations cultural heritage for? Though the museums say they collect for everyone to access, Sentence argues the intended audience for museums was not for First Nations or people of colour. Instead, these archives and museums were designed for colonisers to legitimise colonization, misrepresent “The Other” and falsify history. Sentence concludes that in order for archives and museums to accurately collect and preserve First Nations cultural heritage, they must include First Nations communities in their collections process and conform to such exhibits that require a specific preservation practices.

P.Wellz   2021-02-11 8:26 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Nice one! That's a great connection back to the reading in our Climate history course.

This gets me thinking more about the Eirik the Red Saga. So that saga was written by the ancestors of Gudrid, so they were trying to preserve the memory of past events, glorify their family history, and write it all down with the sensibilities of their medieval Christian upbringing a couple hundred years after the initial events. So if the author's descriptions are influenced by his present circumstances (religion in this case) then we can conclude that memory, and remembering, focuses on past events, but is shaped in the present.

In other words, a museum might have an Indigenous artifact on display, but without the "memory" of that artifact, or its significance to the culture that produced it, it's hardly more than just a material object. In as many words, you need to talk to memebrs of the culture from which the artifact comes in order to understand the memory, or the genuine history and meaning of the thing. Otherwise you lose the grand part of an item's significance, or worse, you misrepresent the object entirely.

That's a bit longwinded, I hope it made sense.

⤷

JoshSkelton   2021-02-22 10:27 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

The article on Collections: How we Hold the Stuff we Hold in Trust, acts as a guide for museums to follow, in order to hold artifacts and exhibits in a non-colonial, and culturally respectable fashion. Different steps and methods are proposed, along with examples of how to go about these methods. The article highlights collaboration and inclusivity, and acts to transform museums from colonial collection hoards into community based centres of culture and history. While the article does not directly quote digital galleries, much of the guidelines set out in this paper apply to digitized museums and collections too. The “Collaborative digital curation and recursive publics: The making of Sq’éwlets: A Stó:lō-Coast Salish Community in the Fraser River Valley” reading (https://mw18.mwconf.org/paper/collaborative-digital-curation-and-recursive-publics-the-making-of-sqewlets-a-stolo-coast-salish-community-in-the-fraser-river-valley/ ) provides an excellent example of how these guidelines can work in practice, to create collaborative relationships for digitized exhibits. The article also refers to multiple digital tools and programs which can be used to help provide information and de-colonize exhibits, examples of this are the graphs, and data mapping programs which can visualize important data in regards to important issues which could be surrounding artifacts in exhibits such as oppression or theft. The overall message of the paper is nice, and opens up an important discussion that many museums need to have in order to properly repatriate and reconcile.

mimiottawa   2021-03-09 4:06 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

For example:

Sandra Benites. She is the very first Brazilian Indigenous curator, from the Guarani people. She is working for the MASP Museum in Sao Paulo. Her goal is to bring not only the Indigenous works of art into museums, but also their voices. Specially considering how Brazilian history and geography books usually do not include the Indigenous voices in their texts. She mentions how the Indigenous people of Brazil is simply ‘not afraid anymore’. Sandra is working hard so the narratives and world vision of the Indigenous people can be heard. Therefore, she is organizing an exhibition with sculptures, paintings, photographs, dance and song performances from Brazilian natives. She mentions how this exhibition is also the concretization of the Indigenous people’s cry. They cry for the deforestation of the Amazon, they cry for the way how mining and hydroelectric stations are destroying their land. She hopes that through art demonstrations, they can have their voices heard, thus a dialogue can be initialized. She also mentions the importance of including the work of Indigenous women into this exhibition.

sianwilliams   2021-02-22 9:34 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
“We talk about race everyday at Eastern State. Our silence on the matter indicates we have nothing to say about it.”

This quote really stuck out to me as it is directly from those who operate within the justice system, and therefore, have a strong voice when it comes to how history is conveyed when we factor in discourse surrounding non-white culture. In a sense, I understand the concept of being silent when it comes to the fact that not everyone can have a shared experience to deliver that would positively impact the topic of race and the justice system. However, with their job being in a historic penitentiary site, discourse should be held regarding racial disparities in the justice system that can be visible even today, especially with black individuals. As it reads following the passage, it is reflective of how ignorance and fear of racial discourse leads to those being misinformed or not informed whatsoever. Furthermore, it is written that "it took an investigation into absences to truly change interpretation", which is something I think is critical when we are reforming the way we convey and discuss history. Even though race is prominently talked about in their exhibit during the writing of this piece, are there any other ways we can think about reforming how we deliver information regarding black individuals and incarceration that invites an open and possibly comfortable discourse about history in the justice system?

sianwilliams   2021-02-22 8:31 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
As a more diverse array of voices form a poly-vocal chorus within museums, all departments—including interpretation—might feel less over-burdened

Through this, it supports similar arguments that can be found in the reading regarding the Sq'ewlet peoples of British Columbia; in the sense that historical institutions are being challenged to provide narratives that are different from westernized and colonial perspectives, further allowing people from all sides of producing, participating and perceiving histories to be well-informed and accurate when it is presented to the public. With historical institutions wanting to diversify the perspectives taken on when addressing non-western history, we can think of all the ways to ensure that every team in charge of creating, preserving and circulating history is able to do so in a way where they aren't feeling over-burdened. Aside from including the poly-vocal chorus in museums and other institutions, how can we ensure that all departments in charge of preserving and sharing historical narratives aren't left to feel burdened through sharing histories?

P.Wellz   2021-02-23 8:12 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Both of those are great points! This discussion makes me think about the Historical Theory class and how in the 19th and early 20th centuries there was a real trend of "historical science" and the "objective historian." The idea being that historians had to have a certain distance from the subject matter to avoid bias and that they could effectively become the experts on any history just through reading and "empirical evidence." Think like armchair anthropologists in the 20's.

Basically these types of historians, almost always white males, wrote as if they themselves were the sole authoritative voices on their given subjects. I think museums inherited a lot of this mentality, and while most historians have moved away from this kind of thinking, it seems to remain in certain museum exhibits. As both of you have said, collaboration with people who have lived experience is the only way to get past this.

jennaemslie516   2021-02-07 8:30 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

In this article, the authors dig into the ethics of GLAM collections and both the past ways that collections have been held and handled and future methods in which they can collaborate with the communities and peoples that the collections come from. Simply, this article offers the beginning of a roadmap to decolonize collections and make museums a collaborative space of knowledge sharing and creation.

They're participating in a larger conversation that museums have been embroiled in for the last three decades - how they should handle their collections, who has the authority to display these items, how should they contend with the acquisition history of the items, and what role should the public have in those decisions. Museums have been (and still are) seen as powerhouses of knowledge - a (mostly) accessible way for people to learn and access information that they might otherwise have. But that power has historically been used to suppress the stories and histories of marginalized communities, people of colour, and non-European societies. These conversations are by no means over, but this article poses thought-provoking and important questions about the ethics of collections and how museums need to change and address these very real issues and concerns.

How We Hold the Stuff We Hold In Trust

There are questions we can ask ourselves to make sure that we are not engaging in appropriative interpretation:

All of these questions relate to the difficult task of relinquishing authority. It can be hard to 'let go' of the expertise you gain through extensive education. We are taught by educational institutions that learning about cultures through the "objective" observations of an author are fair, thorough, and comprehensive, but rarely are the peoples involved included in the authoring of historical analysis or interpretations.

What are ways that we, as historians and scholars, can let go of the authority we hold? How can we legitimize the knowledge and experiences of those whose cultures we are examining and interpreting?

P.Wellz   2021-03-11 6:05 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Oo nice, this is great point about the idea of touch and materiality!

I'm gonna tell a little related story that this reminds me of. I was chatting with a guy in one of my other classes who is from the Manitoulin Reserve and he was telling me how he used to work at the Smithsonian museum dealing with Indigenous artifacts. At the time they were doing a lot of repatriating of artifacts, but there was a problem. As per Western standards of trying to "perfectly preseve things behind glass" they would spray down things like masks with fermaldehyde in order to kill off any bacteria that might eat away at the mask. However, the communities to which they were returning these objects wanted to actually use the masks and put them on, handle them, and use them within their original context of the living culture. I'm sure you can see the problem, given that fermaldehyde and people don't go well together.

Anyway, your point reminded me of this situation and I think it really highlights that the material object is only one part of an artifact, and in many cases things like touch and performance are integral parts of the object's meaning and history.

⤷

P.Wellz   2021-02-11 5:54 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

And to go one step further, taking objects without consent is a violent act in so far as it is stealing, but what the museums do with those artifacts and the stories they tell with these stolen artifacts can be an equally violent act.

For example, I remember Prof. David Dean did a guest lecture for Historical Representations with Prof. Walsh and Dean was talking about some of the early archaelogists and how they would dig up Indigenous artifacts from culturally significant places and then arrange things like the arrow heads in a way that suggested a direct progression from the "primitive savage" to the "civilised European." So in this case not only were the artifacts stolen, but they were further abused when they were used to perpetuate racist narratives. So taking cultural materials without consent is doubly violent.

sianwilliams   2021-02-22 10:54 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
its power from cultural practice—that is, from the production and circulation, reproduction and recirculation, of texts, narratives, languages, and imagery, both literally and figuratively

I think this passage helps us understand how westernized systems hold the power they do. As someone who is of european descent (and having my cultural history very westernized and accessible) and actively sought out in post-secondary to learn about a vast array of history, I was wondering if these sorts of critical questions were something you guys had developing an interest in history or whether it's something that's crossed your minds more recently?

P.Wellz   2021-02-23 8:46 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Yeah I think you have a really good point there that it is the people who have found a cultural artifact and have the means to put it on display that get the sense of power rather than the culture from which the artifact originates.

This makes me think about the fundamental differences in Western and North American Indigenous philosophy and world view. For the West, there is very much a focus on the material, documents especially, and barring that other material objects. There's also a major focus on ownership, as in "I am holding this thing, so it is mine to do with as I will" regardless of the object's origin. So because of this material and ownership focus, you historically get the taking of artifacts with out consent that then get displayed with a totally innaccurate story.

Contrast this with an Indigenous perspective voiced by Barry Ace in a class I took a few years ago, where it is actually the oral history that carries the heart of the story, and that oral history is intimately wound up in both the material object and the person of the community who tells the history. This results in a much more holistic, community based history that relies on people, their relationships, and their material history all at the same time. It is very much a community production of memory. Makes me think about the collaborative community approach discussed in Intrepretation: Liberating the Narrative.

⤷
JacobSpierings   2021-02-25 3:15 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

This passage reminds me of the British's "Operation Legacy" leading up to the independence of their former colony of Kenya. They destroyed thousands of documents and shipped thousands more to London. This is a prime example of how they tried to exert control over the narrative. They understood the power in texts and documents and tried to use this power for their benefit.
sianwilliams   2021-02-22 10:40 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
As such, the majority world’s ostensibly incompetent governance—in a word, its unruliness—is presented as a key factor perpetuating the digital divide, the bridging of which would allow such communities to competently govern their own affairs; the majority world, in short, is standing in its own way

However, in light of my hopes for historical narratives to be completely accessible and equal when placed upon online platforms, we are reminded that government and ICT regulations are vastly different in a global sense. The western systems that provide historical information to the public on a grand scale are also those in which governance is responsible for hindering this bridge that further enables global communities to circulate and disseminate their historical interpretations and knowledge. Furthermore, ICT being incorporated into historical narrative sharing almost seems to be biased implicitly, as those who reside in diverse and agilistic communities might lack a sense of internet and communication technological access we don't question, unlike western societies. In other words, with our society being governed in an almost undisciplined fashion, it therefore allows for other communities to be unable to effectively share and distribute their own narratives, hence the popularized western structures history is seemingly placed into.

sianwilliams   2021-02-22 10:18 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
Non-Western communities are cast here tacitly, appearing only as the information underprivileged and characterized by their positioning outside of histories of information production

Interestingly, I think this passage outlines why I think the shift of history being accessible and easily comprehended through online platforms is SO important for non-western communities to partake in. With museums being primarily materialistic via their exhibits and information that is up for interpretation, it neglects the aspect of cultural and oral history that survives through members of non-western communities, therefore limiting the global range and accessibility for those who aren't apart of these communities. When museums are understood as being representative and reliable of the historical information that is available to the public, it allows the lack of information to be skewed and considered underprivileged, and essentially unworthy of showcasing or informing others about accurately. For all historical narratives to thrive, the amount of accessible information on hand has to be deemed equal and accurate for all communities. Are there ways we can think about how to convey oral and cultural history into the western system museums operate under or would it be more successful if cultures moved to online historical archives they could manage themselves? Or rather, do we need a major reformation to the system museums and historical institutions operate under?

chantalmb   (edited 2021-02-10 6:35 a.m.) 2021-02-10 6:34 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I think this sentence summarizes a lot of the negative feelings I had when reading this article.

Firstly, because this article is meant to speak to museums broadly, I find it implies that creating this network of influencers is "a little" effort on the museum's part. In reality, the The Children's Museum of Indianapolis is literally the world's largest children's museum. Indianapolis is also a large city that both attracts a significant amount of tourism and likely has a number influencers living in and around the city. Any museum located in a less convenient or populous location would not have nearly as much luck attracting influencers to their facility, even through direct invitation, simply because they lack the fame and draw that a big city creates. And then there's the issue of having the funds to invite influencers, which brings me to my second issue.

There seems to be an implication that the work of influencers is something that is easy and cheap. This statement tells me that either they're overestimating the funds that most museums have, or underpaying/not the influencers they "invite", which is a massive ethical issue in my eyes. I'm leaning towards the latter, because, for example, earlier in the article they mention how they can DM their team of "proactively loyal" influencers for campaign feedback, implying this is done for free yet in reality this is consultancy work that should be paid. You also mentioned a "saviour complex" vibe in another annotation that I think applies here too. The article discusses "micro" and "nano" influencers like they're ripe and ready to be exploited due to their smaller audience but more local reach. Larger influencer are often those who have been in the industry longer and aren't afraid to ask for payment, but because of the phrasing "little", after the section about "inviting" individuals with smaller audiences to be influencers, it sounds like they may have taken advantage of that and did the whole "we'll pay you in exposure" kind of thing with promise of networking events or something.

Digital means of connection such as social media can be a valuable way to advertise services and disseminate information, but the way this article presents that feels like it crosses the line of simple social media sharing to exploitation of an "untapped" market.

P.Wellz   2021-02-10 1:22 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

And just to roll with your point about how "online reckonings can be swift and viscious" I think there's something to be said for the consequences of a marketing campaign that is too successful! This article seems to assume that most museums are chronically under visited, which I suspect is true in most cases, but what happens when a tiny underesourced museum suddely goes viral and gets absolutely swamped by visitors?

I'll give a related example. I work in Algonquin Park near the natural waterslide called High Falls. It was once a really well kept secret but in the last few years it has exploded in popularity due to its new presence on social media. So you now have an area of historical and natural interest that is constantly packed to capacity. Garbage gets left behind, there isn't enough parking on the road, crowds mean more risk of injury, and the natural plant growth in the area is totally pounded down by all the traffic. Basically its rise in popularity has been great for the Park financially, but there are also a range of ethical, safety, and practical issues that now urgently need to be addressed.

If anyone wants to take this one step further I think this same concern could be applied to museums quite easily.

Calm technology in museums In Humanizing the digital

My reflections - M Munoz

Sometimes we feel just overwhelmed by all technology surrounding us. It is almost like computers become invasive toward the normal functioning of our human brain.

Even movies, sometimes they are just too much! Last week, I was trying to watch 'The Crowds II' with my kids and all the exaggeration of sound, images and special effects just made us burdened. We could not take it any more. The movie became mentally tiring for us.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wBcBzJ_oofs

When we ponder upon digitalization efforts within museums, I think we need to realize that the excess of stimulus can make people feel just tired; people can lose interest altogether.

I also think technology initiatives within museums should bring into consideration cognitive issues such as autism.

chantalmb   2021-03-14 9:29 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I feel like this section kind of treats accessibility as something extra-- like a "could" instead of a "should". Both in general and when using calm technologies, there needs to be alternatives to the standard text or voice cues and displays for the sake of making an exhibit accessible. I've studied HCI, and a significant part of it is making sure technology (in this case, referring to the digital) is as accessible as it possibly can be in accordance with WAI guidelines. Museums must remember to do this themselves, and with the implementation of calm technologies perhaps create their own accessibility standards for HCI (unless this already exists and I just don't know about it). An exhibit that creates immersion through sound effects or music might produce the desired affect for most, but for those who can't hear it would just be another plain ol' museum exhibit! In this case, something as simple as setting up coloured lights to change with the mood a room is trying to convey could replace sound to reproduce the immersion for those who can't hear, but also add to the music for those who can.

jennaemslie516   2021-03-14 3:11 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I think part of the reason why we haven't really seen much of this approach in wider discussions about museum practices is because they are slow to adapt. The author mentions how, despite decades of studies, museums design exhibits that require a lot of attention instead of taking into account that visitors move through them rather quickly.

I think part of the problem might be that because academics see themselves in positions meant to teach, there is a large sense of "I have to teach them everything." For example, I've noticed that since the onset of COVID, some profs for my classes realized that their students were under a lot of stress, there is more demanding our time and energy and attention, having the expectation that they're going to spend 9+ hours a week on one class is unrealistic and they need to reconfigure their plans to accommodate these massive changes. And then there are profs who continue on like it's a normal semester (and might take off a few readings here and there) and are surprised when their students struggle and can't keep up with the workload.

All of this is to say that there seems to be an existing need that in order to effectively teach someone something, they need the total sum of knowledge you've managed to soak up in your long experience in academia. It's why many classes, especially in undergrad, are so densely packed with information, why museum exhibits focus so much on including as much text as possible: you aren't really learning unless you have all of the information available. What I really like about what this article is suggesting is that learning can be a much more organic and holistic experience, interwoven with what we're already doing rather than adding new layers of barriers that make it difficult to learn anything at all.

Sorry this comment is so long! But you have a lot of great annotations for the article; they've certainly got me thinking a lot, haha.

WilliamKohlman   2021-02-09 7:43 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

This article by Cathy Sigmond discusses how she attended a keynote address about Calm Technology, that detailed the design philosophy of reducing complexity to promote focus and calm to respect people’s “humanness”. While it wasn't aimed at museums, Cathy, a museum evaluator, saw how museums could use the key design principles mentioned.

Calm Technology came out of human-computer interaction studies done by Xerox, by people who thought that technology was becoming too complex and demanding too much of people’s attention. Essentially they saw Calm Technology as a non-intrusive way for technology to seamlessly aid people without them having to divert too much attention to them. Cathy saw this as a way to think about museum exhibitions and how they could be improved by adopting a Calm Technology design philosophy.

Sigmund reiterates original ideas, and expands on them to consider how they could be applied in museums.

A lot of the principles focus on minimizing the cognitive load of using technology so that people can better accomplish what the goal of the technology is. For example, by not overloading people with too much information, museums can maximize their exhibitions’ “successfulness” despite people only spending on average 10 minutes per exhibition. By utilizing technology in a way that only brings attention to itself if required, people are free to think and explore the exhibit and get the emotion, feeling, or message that an exhibit is trying to provide without being distracted. If technology is able to fade into the periphery, so people effortlessly use the technology while still focusing their attention on the exhibit, people would be more likely to have a better understanding of the exhibit. Think of it like using your turn signals while driving, you don’t shift your focus from the road to do it, you do it on the periphery of your attention. Another way museums can introduce technology on the peripheral, is to ensure that the technology communicates, but that it doesn’t necessarily have to speak with people. Using nonverbal cues, such as tones, lights, shape, music, etc. to convey tone and message can be just as effective as a narrated speech, or a plaque describing an event. Additionally, this can work to improve the accessibility of exhibitions. These examples of minimalism in order not to overwhelm people with information or potential areas of attention are important, since anything in excess of what is needed to convey the overarching message can hinder said message. These are the differences between what might be fun to include compared to what is necessary to include. If it doesn’t serve the overarching use and messaging, then it is not needed as it can distract people.

Additionally Sigmund looks at how technology and humans are different, and that they should behave differently, so technology should be used to maximize our unique human qualities. In the context of museums, staff can work to respect people by providing support with things, and then learning from these cases and working to better accommodate the problems they had with the technology in future exhibition. While those might be edge cases and examples of failures of technology, it can also be another chance to get things right. If an exhibit is designed in a way that it requires every single thing to work flawlessly, then it may not be a good design. Redundancy should be built in so that if one aspect fails, the message can still be conveyed either through the “failed” state tech, or through other areas of the exhibit. Failure in this sense isn’t a fail, but areas to improve on in the future. While looking at ways to improve and include new technologies, it is important that social norms and cultures are not exceeded. This goes back to not overloading people. If people are not used to, or are unsure of how to use new technology then they will be unlikely to use them in a museum setting since they are not used to it.

These design principles, as Sigmund envisioned them transitioning to the museum sphere, work to discuss how museums can capture and utilize visitors’ attention, while respecting their “humanness”, in ways that help the museum to achieve their goal better. They place the audience at the center of the exhibit, and focus on how they can design exhibitions to better serve people in today's day and age of attention grabbing technology.

▶  20  Calibrating relevance at the Pitt Rivers Museum www.jstor.org

WilliamKohlman   (edited 2021-03-03 9:20 p.m.) 2021-02-22 10:29 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

This article is written by the Director of the Pitt Rivers Museum, and discusses how they are trying to stay relevant to people as a museum in the current world. The Pitt Rivers Museum is located at the back of the Oxford University Museum of Natural History, and forms part of the University of Oxford. It was founded when General Augustus Henry Lane Fox {itt Rivers donated 27,000 objects. General Pitt Rivers believed that museums should work as places of public education and in order to do so, they needed things of relevance to a wider audience.

The article opens by discussing what Relevance means by examining two ideas from The Art of Relevance by Nina Simon. Van Broekhoven uses these ideas to talk about museums. The first being that some have the notion that they are universally relevant, or that museums will always be relevant because they are important. She contrasts this with the notion of relative relevance, meaning that information is relevant to people based on their own interests and life experiences. The second idea being that “relevance is irrelevant” which is similar to the first in that museums can think that they are so important and necessary that they do not need to seek out relevance. Van Broekhoven points out that this mentality limits museums from creating and opening doors to audiences that they are not relevant for. In her book, Nina Simon argues that a museum matters when it matters to people. Van Broekhoven goes on to explore some statistics that show that the P.R.M. is doing fairly well as a museum based on counting stats such as visitors.

She then goes on to discuss how other fields are always performing calibrations, and tweaking how they operate, and she state that museums should be no different. The current mission statement is “to build and share knowledge about humanity’s many ways of knowing, being, creating, and coping in our interconnected worlds with the widest possible audience”. This mission statement is pointed out to be vastly different than the original objective of the museum that sought to show how objects evolve from the simple to the complex, to explain the conservatism of ‘savage races’, demonstrate how progress has been effected, and outline the stages of civilization that ‘savages’ go through. These contrasting mission statements work to show how the museum has been able to change and calibrate their offerings in order to matter to the people, and to better reflect the artifacts.

The article discusses one of the most discussed exhibits they have, of the shrunken heads, known as the tsantas. The director states that they are one of the most asked about exhibits, and have been praised by numerous people. However she also mentions that certain Shuar and Ashuar representatives(descendants of those that made the tsantsas) at other museums have argued for either the return of them, a better contextualization of them so they do not come off as stereotyping a people, or the removal of the exhibits altogether. Van Broekhoven muses on how museum are often criticized for their interpretations of indigenous cultures and practices by othering the objects of those people. Van Broekhoven believes that more work through conversations with the Shuar and Ashuar would be preferred in order to respectfully display them, as she believes that removing them would be a missed opportunity for inviting in voices that are usually unheard.

Van Broekhoven continues on to discuss aspects of the “decolonize museums’ movement, and argues that the P.R.M. has attempted to make changes where possible to facilitate some of those changes. She readily admits that some of those changes are not visible to visitors currently though, as a previous decision was made in 1998 to keep the status quo of exhibits, while performing academic and collaborative research with affected communities. I think this, while noble, failed to a certain extent since by showing the outdated and colonalist exhibits, they propagated those ideas to the public in a time when they were working to change things behind the scenes.

Van Broekhoven concludes that museums occupy a complex space, but that the P.R.M. believes it is their duty to acknowledge historical wrongs that lie at the root of politics of inequality, and is actively trying to become a museum that can be personally relevant to many people. Finding that relevance involves engaging with troublesome social and political debates, to address the tension between dominant histories and alternative voices, all while trying to inspire their visitors as well. This article serves as one museum’s thought process on how to remain relevant by addressing their previous wrongdoings, and working to include room for all kinds of voices in the world of museums.

kbingham   (edited 2021-03-12 8:55 p.m.) 2021-03-12 8:54 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I have some conflicting feelings about this. On the one hand, I feel that there should be a respectful way to display artifacts grouped by culture or period without falling into the traditional colonialist trappings. However, I realize that this is much easier said than done.

Organizing artifacts by type instead of culture or period helps combat this problem a bit. It is no longer about comparing cultures or depicting them as more or less primitive than others. I once visited a museum that had an exhibit space that worked like this. The exhibit itself was on the art of arms and armour and was separated into different rooms based on the type of weapon or armour. I felt that this brought more attention to the individual pieces themselves and their value as beautifully crafted weapons instead of them attempting to commenting on the cultures they originated from. If that same exhibit had been organized by period, there would have been comparisons of which culture made the most advanced weapons for that period. If it had been organized by culture, then people would compare which culture made the best weapons. I feel that by organizing it by type, the museum avoided these comparisons and kept the focus on the objects themselves.

kateredner   2021-02-23 9:53 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

This article discusses the issues with digital archives and the difficulties surrounding the preservation and maintenance of various digital technologies. One of the main issues with preserving digital archives is the increased volume of items which need to be preserved. Another issue surrounding digital archives involves the various platforms which these artifacts are stored on, and trying to maintain them on appropriate software formats due to their short lifespan. Issues with digital archives span from technical and administrative issues to legal and logistical issues. Several other concerns which are also mentioned in this article are the cost of storage, maintenance, the time it takes to download various items and funding. The reality that there can be multiple copies of one item under multiple locations, names and formats is also addressed, as well as the issue involving the compression and degradation of files as they get uploaded to other external sites. By discussing about these concerns, this article allows the reader to notice these issues and think about what possibilities could be done to help with these problems

rysegaert   2021-02-22 3:55 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
Additionally, most analogue materials are "owned" by institutions, whereas for digital materials, institutions may have access rights only, and only for the period for which they subscribe

This idea has in recent years has changed the landscape and operation of on-line catalogues and library access. As digital formats become the norm for archived and newly released works, collections become increasingly digital themselves. For example, many academic libraries manage a small physical collection compared to what their patrons actually have access to. These institutions subscribe and pay for right of access. This concept takes off the burden of physical digital collections management and some of legal process for the subscribing institution. In result, these catalogues act almost as like resolvers, directing users with the right of access to another institutions database wherein the source is located.
⤷

rysegaert   2021-02-22 1:11 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
Metadata is probably the most important aspect of digital preservation

This is "probably" a true fact. I believe it as a true fact, metadata is the most important aspect of digital information/archive. Metadata gives context to the asset or file it is associated to. Metadata descriptions include descriptive, structural, administrative, reference and/or statistical variables. These descriptions give the accessor context of a file or multiple files without exporting or execution.
⤷
mimiottawa   2021-03-09 7:27 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh

niall_s   2021-03-09 11:16 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I see metadata’s value through the context that it provides. At its most basic, it provides key information about where the data came from and who has handled it etc. Further, metadata has the power to link multiple items together through their commonalities. Without this, materials are situated in isolation and their value is diminished. Metadata provides greater meaning by showing the relationships that materials have with one another. Metadata also allows the viewer to understand how the material is understood at the time that it was preserved.

metadata
context

P.Wellz   2021-03-11 5:17 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh

rysegaert   2021-02-22 1:03 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

We are in the digital age. The fact is, we have never held so much digital data before. This has presented challenges in preserving such vast amounts of data. We understand throughout years of new technologies and formats, preservation of digital assets can become complicated if not strategized correctly. Current practices have proven to be reliable but not infallible for the future, which is why information management organizers must continue to evolve their strategies variable to their collection. Here are some examples of challenges the future of digital preservation will face. The first apparent challenge is the raw volume of this data. Though storage options are becoming more accessible and cost efficient, over time some files apart of larger assets may be up for deletion. As demands for retention increases, only key files that will not be replicated will be saved in the name of storage efficiency. In contrast, multiplicities of the same file seem to be in the name of storage inefficiency. However, having multiple copies of the same thing means less chance for loss of the asset. Another challenge for the future digital of preservation is the software and accessibility. Though current software will remain in use for many more years, older files and formats that rely on software will increasingly become inaccessible. This is a problem for the long term as migration may not work or formats are not supported. In addition to file storage within the software, it is critical for an archive to keep their metadata in line. Metadata is responsible for the accessibility of an archive and its’ catalogue; poor metadata may result in an undiscoverable or unrenderable asset. In addition, a well-organized metadata schema will give an archive context regarding its contents, even as more are added. It is evident that these challenges are not just from technology of the past, but also what is expected from the future.
⤷
mimiottawa   2021-03-09 7:07 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Multiplicity is a challenge even for everyday family digital data management. Sometimes family groups on WhatsApp share the same picture numerous times. We end up with multiple copies, which becomes hard to manage. Just image this issue on large scales!

P.Wellz   2021-02-16 1:26 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Ok, so spark notes version here of the article. Basically everything is going digital these days, which we know already, but as scholars in a field that deals with preservation, that means we have a lot of problems that we're going to have to start considering real soon. Here are a few examples:

It might seem like there are a lot of books out there, but there are nowhere near as many books as digital content. How do we deal with this volume? How do we decide what merits preservation?

File types are always changing, and many files require special programs to run them. So, not only do we have to digitally preserve files, but we also have to preserve the entire infrastructure required to run them.

Modifying and copying stuff for preservation can be dicey because of copyrights laws and privacy rights, so this can make handling digital materials, especially from things like social media or proprietary software, a very sensitive process indeed.

Finally, just like books, we needs somewhere to put all this preserved stuff. And a whole host of staff, hardware, software, and on-going maintenance to keep all this together for future generation of historians.

Seriously, if you're looking for a history career this kinda thing may well be it.

⤷

P.Wellz   (edited 2021-02-16 1:18 a.m.) 2021-02-05 9:37 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

We tend to think of historians as being entirely oriented towards the past. After all, the past is by definition what we study. Sometimes one might think of historians in the present in terms of advocacy work, but what I really like about this article is that it frames our work in terms of the future. Houghton seems to say not so much "How do we protect the past?" but rather "How do we protect against the future?"

We often forget the real technological boom of the 21st century is still so recent, but very soon, maybe already, historians of the modern era will be working almost exclusively with digital material. What will these digital archives that we will all soon rely on look like? Will an archive be just as apt to be a building filled with a super computer rather than with shelves of books and artifacts? How much of our time is going to be spent just trying to maintain our work in the durable way that books do?
⤷
mimiottawa   (edited 2021-03-09 7:21 a.m.) 2021-03-09 7:01 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Excellent points. And also how can we know what type of data will be considered important tomorrow. Sometimes what we don't value today, might be extremely valuable in the future. It is almost like an art of trying to predict the future.
P.Wellz   (edited 2021-02-16 1:13 a.m.) 2021-02-05 9:22 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
Some types of digital media have a generally agreed archival format; TIFF is the accepted format for images, for example.

Time to go photographer mode here. There are different photo formats, jpg being probably the most common one. The issue with jpg however, is that it doesn't retain all of the data that is taken in by the sensors on your camera. Rather, it compresses information in the photo you take and uses automatic processes to gloss over the data that gets lost. Sounds bad, but because of this you get a much smaller file that you can actually use. TIFF on the other hand, has a much higher fidelity and keeps all of the initial data from the photo, but it gives you a way bigger file that your computer needs a special program to handle. So, preserving digital materials involves not just the artifact itself, but also the entire network of hardware and software needed to access the file. Think about it, what would you do if Apple suddenly went out of business and suddenly you had to port all of your files over to a PC. How would that go? Would you go to the effort of saving everything? Or would you accept your losses and leave your files to the abyss?

More info on TIFF vs JPG https://www.richardphotolab.com/blog/post/jpeg-vs-tiff-a-photographers-guide#:~:text=WHAT%20IS%20A%20TIFF%3F,subsequently%2C%20very%20large%20file%20sizes.

niall_s   (edited 2021-03-04 12:43 a.m.) 2021-03-04 12:42 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Preserving intellectual content is of the highest priority in my opinion. While still important, replicating the look and feel of a historical item seems to be a luxury that might need to be bypassed in some cases. Houghton has stressed that there is a limit to the storage and time allowed for the preservation of these materials.

I think these questions of what deserves to be archived should be sorted into short-term and long-term preservation. In the short-term, I am more lenient to extra materials being stored. This might be a stretch, but centuries down the line, it would be impractical to store anything beyond what preserves the essence of the item. Storing technology to replicate things like the original user experience is an unattainable goal for most institutions. Technology is evolving at such a rapid pace and machines become obsolete quickly. A large variety of technology would have to be preserved to meet this need.

I also think that there is a difference in importance between scientific data and things like digital entertainment. Houghton asks the question “what will historians wish that we preserved?” Present day scientific data is more pertinent to serious problems in the future like climate catastrophes. That is the sort of thing that humans in the future will thank us for. I’m not detracting from the importance of digital forms of art etc., but these priorities should be taken into consideration.

⤷

kbingham   2021-03-04 10:11 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Staying on the topic of game preservation, Adobe Flash recently reached the end of its life and has been dropped from major browsers like Chrome and Edge. Flash games are a part of internet history, so people made efforts to preserve them. [Ruffle] is an emulator that was created to solve this problem and allows the flash to be run on the web once one downloads it. Other efforts were made to provide sites to host flash games. The Internet Archive made a software library to preserve some of these games. Although it doesn’t provide the same experience of using sites like CoolMathGames, it does a decent job of preserving the software in a useable form. There are some problems, however, as it seems like the flash games are submitted anonymously, and since they are not on their original site, they do not contain any reference information such as their original publishing date or play count.

I also wanted to comment briefly on game emulation. While emulation of physical games like Orcarina of Time is a good way to preserve the software itself and allow access for future generations, it does come with certain problems. The first one is that it doesn’t preserve what it is like to play the game in its original format. Someone playing Ocarina of Time on an emulator won’t get the same experience they would on a Nintendo 64. They will not be playing it on a low-resolution tube TV, or have to grapple with the N64’s weird controller or have to blow on the cartridge for it to work. The second problem is copyright. Although many emulators have stated that their purpose is historical preservation, Nintendo has attacked them for hosting emulators and ROMs.

kateredner   2021-02-24 8:43 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

In this article, CHIN attempts to create a plan for large and small museums alike that will help with the long-term preservation of digital artifacts. In noticing that various museums had different methods and guidelines for preserving digital artifacts, CHIN conducted a survey to help determine the best preservation practices and procedures. By creating this formal policy, this new procedure will allow all museums to start preserving artifacts under the same method and format for deciding which items should be kept, for how long and under what platform. This research allowed CHIN to be able to examine and identify various issues which arose from the current preservation methods. One issue discusses the probability of CD’s becoming obsolete, and therefore suggests the use of external hard drives instead. Since finalizing the formal preservation procedure, CHIN offers to help implement the recommendations, as well as provide a follow-up assessment within a few years.

kateredner   2021-02-23 6:40 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
Next steps involve CHIN assisting the museum, in implementing these recommendations (or whatever variation is most suitable for the museum), and helping museum volunteers with software training.

I thought this was interesting as I wasn't expecting that they would even help out volunteers with learning software training. What are your opinion's about how CHIN is attempting to help other museums become established with the policy

mimiottawa   2021-03-09 2:24 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Sian Sharing Authority: Creating Content and Experiences My reflections - By M Munoz

Collaboration, Contribution and Co-creation

When I think about the issue of sharing authority within the museum environment, I think about the sharing of authority even among curators themselves. Apparently, there is a ‘camouflaged struggle’ among prestigious academic curators and self-taught curators. Last week, I was able to watch a great movie on Netflix called ‘The Dig’. Please see the YouTube link below.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JZQz0rkNajo

It portraits a landowner called Edith Pretty who hires a local self-taught archaeologist-excavator named Basil Brown to tackle the large burial mounds at her rural estate in Sutton Hoo (near Woodbridge). 

However, the news of the discovery soon spreads, and Cambridge archaeologist Charles Phillips arrives. He declares the site to be of national importance, and takes over the dig by order of the Office of Works.

Brown's contributions to archaeology were recognised ONLY in 2009 by a plaque in Rickinghall Inferior Church.

mimiottawa   2021-03-09 2:03 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Niall https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/9780470996836.ch28 My reflections - M Munoz

When I think about non-Western models of museum curations, the work of Sandra Benites comes to mind. She is the very first Brazilian Indigenous curator, from the Guarani people. She is working for the MASP Museum in Sao Paulo. Her goal is to bring not only the Indigenous works of art into museums, but also their voices. Specially considering how Brazilian history and geography books usually do not include the Indigenous voices into their texts. She mentions how the Indigenous people of Brazil is simply ‘not afraid anymore’. Sandra is working hard so the narratives and world vision of the Indigenous people can be heard. Therefore, she is organizing an exhibition with sculptures, paintings, photographs, dance and song performances from Brazilian natives. She mentions how this exhibition is also the concretization of the Indigenous people’s cry. They cry for the deforestation of the Amazon, they cry for the way how mining and hydroelectric stations are destroying their land. She hopes that through art demonstrations, they can have their voices heard, thus a public dialogue can be initialized. She also mentions the importance of including the work of Indigenous women into this exhibition.

References Knopp, J. G. B. “Transformações Na gestão Da Alteridade: Curadoria Compartilhada No Brasil”. Encontro De História Da Arte, nº 14, dezembro de 2019, p. 687-94, doi:10.20396/eha.vi14.3397.

By M Munoz

chantalmb   (edited 2021-02-10 4:47 a.m.) 2021-02-10 4:43 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
You may also want to take a middle path

Basically, is open data always a good thing?

When I took a class on photography and public history, one of the things we spent a lot of time discussing was how museums and galleries choose to index their collections. kbingham   2021-03-04 7:20 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

One of the benefits of using GitHub is to help combat this problem. Git associates a user, time, and other data like explanations with each change. so you can always check who changed what, when, why, and what it was before the change. Even if something is changed, using Git means that it won't be lost, can be recovered, and has an attached explanation with the reasoning for the change.

Git
GitHub
⤷
kbingham   2021-03-04 7:50 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

This is a very valid concern that I actually believe can be solved with GitHub. You address a couple of concerns here; knowing what data has been altered and how it differs from the original, who is authorizing corrections, and justifying those corrections or proof of their validity. The blame system for Git changes offers possible solutions. The blame system keeps track of what changes were made to the data (before and after), when it was changed, who changed it, who authorized it, and an explanation for the change. If an institution keeps multiple branches (versions) of its data, there can be an original and a working branch with changes on it. Anyone could see what changes were made, and if the Git server is managed correctly, the explanation and justification for the change by those who submitted and authorized it.

Git
GitHub
Collaboration
⤷
chantalmb   2021-03-08 2:04 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Absolutely, GitHub is an excellent platform for addressing and monitoring the issues of accountability and modification of data thanks to the fact that, with git being a version control system, you can track every change made. I think one of the key problems with GitHub, as touch on in this article, is lack of technical training that makes understanding how to view and interpret something like the blame system difficult and intimidating. For your solution to work, both those managing the data and the user need to understand how git works, and how to navigate GitHub's interface. Even beginner users my not be aware of how to view the git blame, so how might institutions make it so that all users accessing the data they publish on GitHub can easily see the changes? Is it even their responsibility to ensure those accessing their data know how to do this?

▶  7  Build It and They Will Come? Patron Engagement Via Twitter at Historically Black College and University Libraries pdf.sciencedirectassets.com

chantalmb   2021-02-10 4:17 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
In simple terms peopleused positive words for tweets around recent athletic wins or schoolpageants, than in tweets about a new library database or a change inoperating hours.

It's well established that social media algorithms favour content that encourages engagement, thus accounts that attempt to actively engage with their following tend to be more likely to succeed. What the results of this data do not account for is the labour required to generate curated content. We see that institutional boosterism results in the most successful engagement on twitter, because this form of post is both simple to create and entertaining. To create positive engagement with a library's contents on social media without stripping the content of its meaning requires a more multidisciplinary effort that is difficult without a dedicated social media team (or further, without funding to introduce new projects and technologies to libraries in the first place).

▶  19  Collaborative Digital Curation and Recursive Publics: the Making of Sq’éwlets: A Stó:lō-Coast Salish Community in the Fraser River Valley – MW18: Museums and the Web 2018 mw18.mwconf.org

JoshSkelton   2021-02-22 2:25 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
How are these sociotechnical systems dependent on the creation of relationships, and, how are those relationships enacted? In 2014, in the initial planning stages of our Virtual Museum of Canada exhibition, Sq’éwlets leadership and community Elders gathered at the Stó:lō Research and Resource Management Centre (SRRMC) in Chilliwack, BC, to discuss and begin to define the central themes of the virtual exhibit.

By using these systems to build relationships with the Sq'ewlet and Sto:lo communities, the virtual exhibits were portrayed through the lens of their own culture. Instead of a whitewashed exhibit, told through the lens of an outsider, these exhibits were created and themed with consideration and input from their respective communities, giving voice back to their own history.

kbingham   2021-03-04 11:47 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I believe it can, as long as digital copies of artifacts are used to repatriate them back to their originating culture instead of museums keeping the original and returning the digital copy. I think that new digital methods of preservation and historical representation could be revolutionary for representing histories in more culturally sensitive ways. It not only allows for digital versions of artifacts to be preserved and displayed, but it also allows cultures to represent their own history in their own way. Traditionally, European-style museums have had a monopoly on historical representation, and part of the reason for this seems to be accessibility. Not only are they large and often in high population areas that allow them to be accessed by a broad audience, but their style of presenting history with physical objects is familiar to most people, and therefore more accessible and easy to consume. Not only does digital representation allow for much larger audiences to access cultural histories, but removing the barrier of a physical museum reduces the preconceptions of the audience of what a museum should be, allowing for different ways of presenting history.

This paper, written by a large collaboration of authors which includes leadership from the Sq’ewlets tribe, describes a recent initiative of Canadian archaeologists, historians and community leaders in creating a digital exhibit and archive on the history of the Sq’ewlets people. ▶  11  Archives strengthening historical narratives: Sharing digital and linked data resources for broader reach and sustainability – MW18: Museums and the Web 2018 mw18.mwconf.org

P.Wellz   2021-02-16 1:44 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

It's a little hard to understand the idea behind the site's organization without actually interacting with the site, so I wanted to post a link to the collection, but as I have just found out, the page is not yet published for public use on the website. Sorry everybody, you'll just have to look really hard at the pictures and hope you get the gist of it. That's what I did...
P.Wellz   (edited 2021-02-16 1:42 a.m.) 2021-02-16 1:40 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

So, in this article Coffey, Watts, and Degler are talking about an online archive that handles recorded oral histories, photos, books, and many other artifacts and media that relate to the history of the Texas Coastal Bend. This article is less about the history of the place and much more so about the organization and function of the web archive itself.

The main thing to know from this article is that navigation through the website relies on the relationships between the files, whether they be audio recordings of oral history, or photos, or what have you. Key to this is effective metadate in each files that allows the web designers to link every single item undre different topics, categories, and subcategories. The idea being that once you pick something to look at on the website it will suggest other related items that you can look at afterwards. In doing this, you get deep into the site and see more stuff, but you all get a sense for the basic relationships between people's stories. This is essential since, even though this is a digital archive, the authors very much view this as a human, living history nevertheless.

The point here is to show other historians in the GLAM sector an effective way of organizing an online archive and it is for this reason that the authors have made this archive open source. This way, the site's assetts and code can be "recycled" and used by other historians to help them get their own archive off the ground.

P.Wellz   (edited 2021-02-16 1:30 a.m.) 2021-02-06 9:49 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
Related content is generated from the rich entity/theme/subject data structure and delivered as the site is used, so it is enhanced as the content and metadata is enhanced.

Again referring back to Houghton's, "Preservation Challenges in the Digital Age" metadata is a huge part of any digital material in a collection. Without good metadata, a file you might have is effectively useless because you would never be able to find on your database, and even if you did. you might not have any idea what it is, who created it, when it is from, etc.

Pulling from my own experience, take a just a quick look at the link below for the Algonquin Park Archives Online and tell me what you think about the organization of this websites and in particular what you think of the metadata on artifacts as well as the site's search function.

https://algonquinpark.pastperfectonline.com/

rysegaert   (edited 2021-03-05 2:53 a.m.) 2021-03-05 2:52 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I agree, metadata is a huge part of any digital collection. Structured encoded metadata allows for accessibility, context and sometimes the tangibility of a collection or resource.

I think the Algonquin Park Archives website navigates well. They provide tips and definitions for searching. Moreover, they provide a keyword and advanced search options for their collection. Using the basic keyword, I search "canoe sailing". In execution 741 results show, some pictures of canoes no sailing at a glance, lots unrelated. Alternatively, I used the advanced search where they offer the option to punch in variables. I use "canoe" in the [title] and "sailing" in the [description]. In execution, 1 result shows; a picture of a canoe sailing. Goes to show you the influence defining metadata values has on search.

As for the metadata enhancement, this seems to be a smaller collection and therefore maybe underdeveloped. Some metadata; search terms and object seem to be outliers. I believe with continuous use and expansion things get more relevant...

P.Wellz   (edited 2021-03-05 4:40 p.m.) 2021-03-05 4:39 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Hey right on! I'm really happy you took the time to check out the Park archives!

Don't get me wrong, I like Park Archive a lot, it's very handy in some situations, but there are a few critiques that I have.

One being that the metadata is lacking. Some of their photos and artifacts are labelled well, but a lot of them have very little other than a catalogue number on them. So while they have a good search function, as you saw any keywords tend to pop up a lot of unrelated images, and I bet that there are plenty of photos that are related to your search that simply don't pop up.

Secondly, that search function is pretty much the only way to explore these archives. They have a random images search to check things out, but what I really like about this Texas collection is that they have set up so that somebody can follow a path through their archives without having any specific things they're looking for. The Texas collection metadata allows them to organize the site in a way that the site itself can guide you through the history and relationships between people rather than having to have specific interest to search for before you start.
