SaraHarvey   2021-03-04 6:06 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

These are some great questions! I have never done research like this, so I am just speculating here. I think that to a degree it cannot hurt for the historian to make connections with the community they are researching. Obviously not everyone will be able, or should, fully immerse themselves/become a member, but I think in some cases it can help as you can develop a deeper understanding and create connections that could allow you more access than that of an outsider. However, it is also important to be objective in research, so getting involved could make it a lot harder to do this. I do think you should form relationships with members of the community, but also be able to give back and not just have it be a one-sided relationship. I think shaping their interviews as a "social event for reminiscing" makes it sound casual and more like a talk between neighbours/friends, rather than an interview with a researcher, which could be intimidating to some. By creating a more casual environment I think some people might be more open to telling deeper stories, or divulge information that they would not normally tell. Doing this has mutual benefits as the researchers can get what they want, and the participant does not feel like they are under a microscope. Basically, I think to some degree the researcher does need to develop relationships, but they also need to be able to recognize there will be spaces and places they cannot go, but they should still try to make it a mutually-beneficial relationship.

jennaemslie516   2021-03-03 11:14 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

This is a discussion I've often had in public history classes. In many ways, digitization makes collections available to people who would have otherwise had a very difficult time accessing it. (If an archive with the materials you need for research are in England and you live in Canada, it is a considerable expense to travel to just examine the materials than if they were available on a website.) I also think there is always going to be the issue of training - students who study archival work will be well-versed in digitization; it will be actively reshaping the entire field of work. Whereas for archivists who have been working for 20+ years, or even just those that are extremely wary of digitization and advocate for traditional means of archiving, I think a tension exists there about the changes in the field. And I think whether this creates a separation or integration largely depends on the consistency of training and practices and a need for increased digital literacy. I feel like I haven't really answered the questions you posed (whoops, haha), but I think many of these issues are going to be rooted in the context of institutional levels and resources, and even by country since archival practices and digitization vary so much from place to place.

Digitizing artifacts seems to benefit all parties. By scanning artifacts into 3-D images and publishing them online, this democratizes information. One of the themes that have recurred throughout the readings is the accessibility of museums and their histories, and digitizing is able to fulfill this. Macdonald also highlighted that as museums become more specialized and more of a focus is placed on working-class and minority communities, their collections work to reinforce and give legitimacy to group and place-based identities. Digitizing these collections are a means of preserving items which are most at risk of being forgotten.

In regards to repatriation, like how you mentioned in another annotation, digitizing artifacts of another culture is fraught with legal and ethical questions, and these need to be navigated carefully with guidance from the respective cultures. That being said, digitizing artifacts is the first and best step historians have available to return artifacts to their rightful places and also preserve their essence in our own museums.

One of the many arguments that comes up when discussing repatriation and the ownership of artifacts is if a location based identity can be considered the rightful owners of an artifact. JoshSkelton   2021-02-20 10:15 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

In the article on Collecting Practices, Macdonald breaks down the overall practice of collecting as a whole. She goes into detail about the history of collecting and how the collection of objects in the early modern period became a status symbol and a social interaction. She describes the evolution of the practice and the methodology along with it, such as cataloguing and how the practice of collections became modern museum collecting. She breaks the article down into sub-sections which describe the methods and significance of collecting and the issues with them. This gives a good background to the overall issues associated with modern day museums and the concept of “ownership” over cultural objects. At one point when describing “individual collecting, she takes a psychological approach to the reasoning behind collecting, which I found strange but an interesting way to interpret the reasoning one would have to keep a collection. It also touched on the idea of intertwining a collection with identity, which relates to the collecting practices of the early modern period as the objects and artifacts in one’s collection could display many things about them, such as their wealth, education, and tastes. The emphasis on collecting outside of museology and how it is a form of consumerism was very interesting as it can be related back to the context of museums through the commodification of artifacts and other museum related content, and the sense of value placed on these items for their status as either “exotic” or “ancient”. The emphasis on ownership and the transformation of individual collections into exhibits and museums themselves is very important as it highlights the origins of many issues museums have with repatriation in the modern era, one key issue being ownership and who these artifacts belong to in both an individual sense, but also cultural sense.

niall_s   2021-02-04 11:36 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Kreps examines non-Western forms of curation by looking at how other cultures approach the preservation of their history. The second section explores how museums are implementing these curation methods into their own practises. There is a particular focus on North American indigenous peoples, and tribes in the Malay archipelago.

This article is part of the post-colonial discourse in historical theory. Kreps reflects on Western museums as a vessel of power, in that it discounts the validity of other curation practises. The Western knowledge system has dominated how we consider artifacts from other cultures. Kreps seeks to free museums from that restrictive way of thinking. Kreps approaches this topic using comparative museology. By studying the differences in curation practises across cultures and contrasting Western museums with its alternatives, historians can gain a larger understanding of our own methods. We can also gain a greater appreciation for curation as a unique cultural expression.

Kreps argues that curation of history is a social practice, situated within a cultural framework and designed to serve a certain purpose. Western museum curation is often considered to be the obvious method to preserve history, but Kreps seeks to disrupt this perspective. By studying non-Western models of museums, historians can understand how people in various cultural contexts value and preserve their historical artifacts. Other forms of curation are examples of human diversity too.

There are high stakes to ‘liberating culture’ as Kreps puts it. Artifacts from other cultures lose part of their identity when they are curated in a Eurocentric manner. By embracing various cultural perspectives in museums, people’s control over their own heritage can be restored. Western museums would also benefit from representing a wide range of cultural perspectives and representing history that has previously been ignored. This would create a museum experience that is reflective of the diverse world that we live in. Accomplishing this would be one step in decolonizing historical practises.

colonialism
curation
museum
power
culture

According to post-colonial theory, historians have advocated for returning artifacts to their locations where they originated. It is clear that the rightful repatriation of artifacts taken in the past is a responsibility that our generation of historians must tackle. Is there a way to meet this challenge while still displaying foreign artifacts to stimulate the public’s interest about the wider world? Or are global exhibits a relic of colonial attitudes? What are possible solutions to this?

kbingham   (edited 2021-02-24 7:59 p.m.) 2021-02-24 7:58 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I agree that the colonialist nature of global exhibits needs to be addressed. However, I believe that there is still great value in international exhibits separate from the exercise in colonial power they have been. International exhibits expose guests to cultures far from their own, allowing for opportunities to expand one’s worldview to those who might otherwise only be exposed to their own culture. I may just be pessimistic saying this, but I believe that in North America, people can be caught up in their own worldview with little care for the wider world. Since they have only had the opportunity to be immersed in their own culture, it is easy to lose sight of other cultures’ values and decide that the American way is THE way to live. The hope is that with opportunities like international travel or exhibits, people will have the opportunity to broaden their horizons and, in doing so, learn to respect cultures that are different from their own. The difference between international travel and museum exhibits presenting global cultures is that when travelling, one is immersed in a culture as it presents itself without external modification. (unless one is on a Eurocentric tour, instead of actual cultural immersion.)

One option to capitalize on this benefit of global exhibits while also combatting their colonialist origins is to refocus them towards honest cultural exchange. Give partial control over the artifacts and exhibits to the cultures they originate from and worth with them to preserve and present the artifacts in a way that better represents the culture they originate from. Additionally, it could be helpful to offer the same type of cultural exchange in return so that it is a genuine cultural exchange, instead of just one culture taking from others. This way, international exhibits could act as actual windows into culture instead of representing dominance from one culture over another.

JacobSpierings   2021-02-07 7:51 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
by roughly the mid-nineteenth century, the principles of the new form were everywhere apparent: everyone, at least in theory, was welcome

Museums came into existence through making personal collections accessible to the public. This step reflected the political change of the 19th century and was in theory, to provide access to the general public, artifacts of power and education. Questions of accessibility are still a central part of conversations around the democratization of museums as well as dynamics of power and control that are ongoing today. Accessibility is an issue that appears to be as old as the modern museum itself, almost two hundred years old.

▶  2  Build It and They Will Come? Patron Engagement Via Twitter at Historically Black College and University Libraries pdf.sciencedirectassets.com

WilliamKohlman   (edited 2021-03-03 9:19 p.m.) 2021-02-22 5:57 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Since Chantal and I both chose the same reading, Chantal proposed that we team up and collaborate on writing the Reading Overview and the Page Prep annotations. We agreed to divide the labour with Chantal writing the annotations and I would write the Reading Overview. Ultimately, this article is about looking at how Historically Black College and University academic libraries utilize Twitter to engage with their audience.

This article details the findings from a study on Twitter activity from sixteen Historically Black Colleges and University (HBCU) libraries. In doing prior research, mots studies that examined academic libraries’ use of Twitter focused on research intensive universities while ignoring smaller college libraries. The broad question that Stewart and Walker wanted to explore was whether or not users were engaging with the content that libraries generated on Twitter. They focused on HBCUs since they can give insight into how smaller libraries use Twitter, as well as libraries that serve a large number of minority students.

They measured ‘engagement’ by looking mainly at retweets, as well as a sentiment analysis of tweets discussing library content. The article starts with a literature review, looking at other studies of academic libraries and their use of Twitter. Some findings include that constituent units and students made up the majority of retweets, approximately 30%. Other studies explored the content of the libraries tweets, finding that the most used words were “open”, “special collections”, and “save-the-date”. Stewart and Walker again made it evident that these other studies were done on large and elite universities.

This study captured Twitter activity from 16 HBCU’s libraries from December 2013 to July 2015, and they used the IBM Watson Analytic Engine. They found that the largest collection of tweets were made by the Huston-Tillotson University, with a total of 3197, while the least was from the Mississippi Valley State University with 1 tweet. One of their broad questions they hoped to answer with this study was whether or not a library's followers were engaging with their content or not. To do this they looked at mentions and hashtags. They found that there was no universal use of hashtags, as some libraries used multiple ones to identify their content, others rarely did. Of those that used hashtags, most were about general topics instead of the specific school or library. The study found that only 11% of followers retweeted library content. However, 60% of the tweets propagated, due to the activity from non-following accounts.

While they found that a large percentage of libraries did not create library specific content, and instead they focused on ‘boosterism’ relating to campus sporting events, popular culture, etc.. They hypothesize that this may be because the majority of libraries in the study were from smaller colleges and universities meaning that they likely had to work more to gain a following compared to libraries at larger institutions. An example of the sentiment analysis can be seen here, as tweets about athletic wins, and other school events were mainly met with positive tweets, less positive words were used in tweets about operating hours changing or new library databases, which scored negative and neutral respectively. Stewart and Walker believe that library specific content was not engaged with to a large extent because the libraries did little work to engage with their followers. The main findings of this study were that these academic libraries tended to use Twitter as a broadcasting medium, instead of as social media. However the study was limited by the low number of active twitter accounts of HBCUs, as well as a low tweet count for some with Twitter accounts, however the findings are sound and raise questions on if Twitter accounts are beneficial for academic libraries at all, and if so, what information should be prioritized?

Social Media
Libraries
Twitter
Topic Modelling
Technology
Library
WilliamKohlman   (edited 2021-03-01 8:44 p.m.) 2021-02-22 5:59 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh

▶  7  Caveat Venditor? Museum Merchandising, Nonprofit Commercialization, and the Case of the Metropolitan Museum in New York www.jstor.org

niall_s   2021-02-21 5:15 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
admissions (i.e., the museum equivalent to fees for service),

One of the primary forms of commercialization are admission fees. Museums have been reliant on variants of pay-to-access income to finance themselves since public funds and endowments declined several decades ago. Museums typically have a mission statement that affirms their role as a public institution. Do admissions contradict the public mission of museums? This leads to a bigger question over what role museums should have in our communities. Should museums act as accessible community resources or as a generator of revenue, engaging in social entrepreneurship? What sort of balance should exist between the two sides of the spectrum?

chantalmb   2021-02-23 4:34 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I felt very conflicted when considering admission fees both as discussed in this article and in my own experiences attending museums. I think museums are incredibly important; they act as both a centre of research and also as a means of disseminating their discoveries to the public. Not only are they a place where children and adult alike can go to engage with a subject learn beyond what they might in a class, but museums are also home to digitized archives that can make their collections (or at least, some of it) available to researchers globally. The work museums do is immense and they deserve payment for it so that it may continue, thus from this angle admission fees feel completely valid.

From another point of view though, admission fees also feel like they're creating yet another barrier to accessing further education. Education shouldn't only be seen as necessary if it's in the setting of a public school; and even if a trip to the museum is associated with school, if you're someone on a tight budget trying to make sure you can have enough for groceries for your family that month, the museum admission fees that still must be paid for a school field trip are at the very bottom of your list of things to spend on. An institution claiming to be for the public yet charging a fee to even enter the building seems dishonest, and frankly contributes to the poverty cycle within the community which the museum is situated by restricting further education to those who can't afford it. Like, I know so many fellow history majors whose love for history started in a museum; how many people are missing that "spark" moment because of admission fees?

With all the information we have access to, why are museums not using more of it or changing with the times? This can be a question you can answer, but I meant it more in terms of this could be a question visitors ask once they compare.

Nice one! I just want to give a personal example to illustrate what you're talking about.

In third year I took a course called Indigenous History: Red Atlantic that focused on the travels of Indigenous peoples from North America to Europe. shawn.graham   2021-02-24 6:48 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

The internet flattens content: everything is presented as if it is equally valuable. The early web used hand-curated lists to deal with this problem; early Google used the structures of interlinkages between pages as a signal of quality (but, crucially, of what people would link to, not scholarly quality). So we have had to create strategies to deal with this - your old grade school teacher telling you to look for ".org, not .com" etc (which is crap).

So dis/information researcher Mike Caulfield has come up with what he calls 'The Four Moves' to deal with informational uncertainty/overload:

  1. Stop
  2. Investigate the source
  3. Find better coverage
  4. Trace claims to their source.

This takes a lot more work - at least, on the surface- but these steps can be done quite quickly. But what I'm getting at: what would a similar approach look like in terms of a museum - and would that look the same in a physical museum versus its digital representation?

sift

kbingham   2021-02-10 2:19 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Topic: “The (post) digital visitor: What has (almost) twenty years of museum audience research revealed?” was written by Lynda Kelly and published February 16, 2016, as part of that year’s Museums and the web conference. * Historiography*: This paper contributes to twenty years of discussion on improving museums with digital methods to fit evolving guest expectations and new learning styles.

Organization: The paper is organized chronologically with two main data sets, one from 1999-2004 and another from 2007-2015. It then follows those observations up with more explanation of how the results of this audience research should be addressed.

Method: While she does reference some other sources, Kelly’s main source is her own papers and experience conducting museum audience research.

Argument: Kelly makes the argument that museum audience research shows a growing number of people, especially students, are learning in new ways driven by digital innovation. She argues that technology is changing the ways people learn, and museums need to adapt to these new learning styles. These new learners have grown up surrounded by technology and are used to instant access to information, seeking out answers, and social learning. She argues that increased synergy between physical, digital, and social elements of museums is necessary to meet these new learners’ needs.

So what?: This reading is interesting because it offers a glimpse into the challenges museums face in catering to a public that has always present instant access to information. Its use of audience research to show how museum audiences perceive their own learning styles frames the author’s recommendations as the result of an ongoing discussion between audiences and historical institutions on how best to present history. For those in heritage or education fields, it provides valuable insight on how new generations’ increasingly digital lives has facilitated large changes in the ways we learn new

P.Wellz   2021-02-11 8:41 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh

kbingham   2021-02-11 10:40 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I like the use of engagement instead of fun, and it feels more respectful when you are trying to depict some of the less PG parts of history. Engagement is also likely more critical for learning than fun since you don't need to be having fun to learn, but you do need to be engaged.

However, when trying to decide what is 'fun' I think we need to look a the fun experts, kids. From personal experience working with kids, being around kids, and being a kid at one point myself, I noted that kids seem to be having the most fun when they are pretending. They love immersive experiences like Disney World that allow them to disconnect from reality, and they even pretend things that adults consider hard work, like construction workers or doctors. Perhaps that is why the Trench recreation at the War Museum, or the opportunity to try on military gear presented in the WW2 section, seemed fun to me as a child; it allowed me to pretend I was something else. While I admittedly had no concept of the gravity of the things I was enjoying, it did increase my interest in those subjects and caused me to seek out more information about them. While this tendency to have fun by pretending does not fully apply to adults, we still find role-playing engaging. Offering up opportunities to 'jump into history' is fun for kids because they get to pretend and likely couldn't understand well enough for the unpleasant realities of what they are pretending to bother them. Meanwhile, the role-play offered by these experiences is still engaging for adults and offers a valuable opportunity for empathy as one tries to imagine themselves in another's shoes.

engagement

I think in this context the best way to make something 'fun' is to gamify it. Adding some kind of progression, challenge, and/or rewards can really help keep people engaged.

P.Wellz   2021-02-12 1:42 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

Re your point about jumping into history for kids, I really like that idea! This is one thing that we have to remember about museum exhibits, is that they are very much "Public history" It's easy for us as history students to get all bogged down rigidly focusing on nuance, complexity, and contingency, but we have to remember who the audience is at all times. Not that we should ignore these ideas but it's absolutely true that kids are kids, and if they are the audience we have to tailor our historical representations towards them, even if those representation don't then always convey that grim gravity of events that we as adults and historians think of. We have to give kids a fun way into history early so that they can then go on to think more critically about the stories they've been told when they grow up.

▶  1  Caveat Venditor? Museum Merchandising, Nonprofit Commercialization, and the Case of the Metropolitan Museum in New York www.jstor.org

niall_s   2021-02-06 5:56 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

This article explores the commercialization of non-profit organizations as they are confronted with a lack of public funds. Toepler employs a case study of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City, following their financial activities from 1960 until 2002. It reflects on how museums should operate given their role as a public good.

The article is organized chronologically. Toepler separates the case study into periods of time, according to the state of commercialization at the Metro (the origins, the rise, and the plateau.) The article is designed to understand what the future of commercialization holds for nonprofits, so tracing its history as context is valuable to the argument. It draws from the Annual Reports of the museum to gain insight into the finances as well as the strategy from the perspective of the director.

Toepler establishes that economic hardships initiated the decline of both private endowments and public funding which contributed to the need for more business-like practices to increase revenue. This includes but is not limited to selling merchandise, increasing global appeal, and ‘blockbuster’ exhibits. Toepler urges for additional investigation into the impacts of commercialization on non-profit organizations as economic conditions change and the growth of commercialization stagnate.

It is important to resist the commercialization of museums. The main concern that is raised is that in the pursuit of revenue-generating business ventures, the public mission of the museum goes out of focus. The museum exists to preserve heritage, and that objective should not change. This article proves that the public funding of GLAM institutions is critical to its functioning and is the only reliable source of income. Governments often leave these institutions vulnerable to budget cuts. Merchandising and similar approaches do not act as complete safety nets however. Downturns in the economy leaves museums without a guaranteed revenue stream.

chantalmb   2021-02-24 2:31 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

This is a very important point you highlighted and also intrigued me when I was reading through the article. I think it's fair to state that GLAM institutions have historically been pretentious spaces primarily occupied by those who were upper-class. Much of the first spaces seen as archives (at least, in the Western world) were formed by men who prioritized political and war-related documents and saw what remained as irrelevant*, thus these institutions were born on elitist foundations. If museums are public institutions, then I feel that they should reflect the public they are open to in the histories contained within their exhibitions, which means moving away from this exclusionary past. The knowledge presented needs to be expertly curated, yet understandable and accessible by the public.

It's surprising to me that 86% of visitor's tags did not match any of the museum's reference labels; 2.0 tech needs to reflect this need for information accessibility-- digital archives need to be tagged with words not just known by specialist researchers, but common language so that anybody can search and easily find an item even if they don't have exact terminology correct. The allowance of public collaboration when forming collections seems incredibly valuable for this purpose, because it allows the community to help curate an archive they can use, and experts can learn more about the language needed to engage the public.

e age of the blockbuster exhibition. Th

Blockbuster economics is a particularly worrying trend in the business strategies of museums. If museums are operating to generate revenue, it makes me wonder how this impacts the type of exhibits they will show. With the pressure to succeed in the mass market, museums will mount exhibits that are guaranteed to be popular and in turn profit. Historical integrity would likely take a back seat. Museums might be influenced to include histories that avoid controversy and do not challenge power. For example, Canadian museums might shy away from covering indigenous history because it contradicts the Eurocentric Canadian history that Canadians are familiar with.

chantalmb   2021-02-23 4:01 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

In contrast with your thoughts, I think that presently, something that would be considered a "blockbuster exhibition" IS an exhibition that generates controversy or at least discusses a subject that may have typically been ignored. With the rise of social media and the increasingly rapid dissemination of information, the current generation of internet-users is more socially conscious than ever before. Reading this article, I realized that what seemed to be a blockbuster in the 70s is... pretty standard to us now. An exhibit dedicated to Ancient Egypt and their royalty is something I would expect to find at any large history/art museum. Modern museum-goers want something different, and museums know that to maintain patronage, they must appeal to this; if they want to capture our attendance, they must present something new and relevant which often necessitates risk-taking. If you look at this list of "must-see" exhibits of 2020, between the typical Eurocentric narratives, there's also exhibits exploring slavery and concepts of masculinity.

Beyond appealing to the current generation though, there's also the realization that in crafting an exhibit that may be controversial, a museum can attract media attention which in turn attracts revenue. I think the more appropriate question for this type of "blockbuster" exhibition is asking how ethical it is to profit off of the stories of those who are still facing consequences of these histories-- on one hand, topics that have been historically ignored are being brought to the forefront of museums, but on the other hand, what consequences may come with an exhibit like this only being created due to "trendiness"?

rysegaert   2021-02-23 1:46 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
Panel 2: Supporting Research: Digital Black Culture Archives for the Humanities and Social Sciences

20:00-25-34

Here the panellists discuss the challenges that arise when journalists critique private and public forums. When it comes to digital research in these sectors of forums, it is important to understand the communities context. Critiquing public utterances is typically not as disciplinary, this is due to its' wide accessibility and comprehension. As well, writers do not need to ask for permission when critiquing. On the other hand, private forums of communication tend to have a community backed context that takes time to build on and comprehend. As conversation develops in these private scenarios, it's suggested that their are higher levels of challenging or controversial topics that could be misinterpreted to a criticiser from the outside; not actively involved in the context of the forum.

Sara's paper: https://www.jstor.org/stable/24587086?seq=1#metadatainfotab_contents

My reflections

It is interesting to see how technology is transforming communication patterns among museums and their visitors; the communication road is no longer one way only. Anyone can disseminate information over the internet about a museum or a collection. Visitors can also talk about their personal experiences when visiting museums. We have seen how such institutions exercise their presence over the web and also over social media. The internet allows museums to interact with their audiences in a very dynamic manner.
So many museums have joined Facebook and have ‘conquered’ millions of ‘friends’ who follow them and leave comments.
This communication reciprocity allows visitors to affect the way museums address their audiences. Now… How can museums control public comments? How can they keep their online reputation? How can they manage negative comments?

Some comments can be really hard to orchestrate. For instance, if you go to the ‘trip advisor website’, you can find really negative comments/reviews about the Museum of Nature here in Ottawa. Please see below a complaint from a visitor and the museum’s response.

https://www.tripadvisor.ca/AttractionReview-g155004-d282693-Reviews-CanadianMuseumofNature-Ottawa_Ontario.html

Kelli O wrote a review Jan. 2017 48 contributions 35 helpful votes

“Worst experience! So I brought my 2 adult daughters to see the reptile exhibit (my older one loves reptiles and has one herself) Biggest disappointment. Hardly any reptiles, no one giving information about them, and if you are going to advertise about reptiles, you should have something very unique (most were just snakes) You are better off going to Little Ray's, and I am being honest.

Secondly the volunteer's are VERY rude. My Daughter's sat down to look at the leaf table (no one was there) they were genuinely interested and started to design some leaves on the paper provided. A volunteer named "Christianne" came over and said "this is for children" and gave them the dirtiest look and kept hovering over them rudely. My older Daughter stood up, she grabbed her paper with leaves on it, and crumpled it up in front of her. Some children came to the table finally, they wanted to colour, but she grabbed the leaves from my younger Daughter and told them they were to play with the leaves.

We paid over $65 for admission for 3 people, (plus 12 for parking!) and after that promptly left. Was not worth even close to that.

you would think a Museum would want people to learn and explore, this is not the case here. the volunteer's/staff were neither helpful or polite.

I really hope they read this and take action. your volunteer made my Daughter's feel awful and in turn I felt horrible for even bringing them as no one deserves to be treated like that. We will not be returning and take our complaint higher. If you do not want young adults to learn or participate you should make that clear before you charge us for admission!”

Date of experience: January 2017

Response from museumofnature, Communications Officer at Canadian

Museum of Nature Responded Jan. 29, 2017

“Thank you for your comments. As a national museum and major attraction in the National Capital Region, we want to ensure the best possible experience for our visitors. Feedback such as yours is very, very important.    We’re sorry that you were disappointed with our current Reptiles exhibition. It is a travelling, educational exhibition from an accredited zoo in the United States and has been received quite well by our visitors. It’s unfortunate that it didn’t meet your expectations.   We deeply apologize for the experience you had at the hands-on botany station. The intention there is to have the plant-mounting activity for adults and a paper leaf craft for children. We’re very sorry that your daughters had a negative experience with a volunteer at that station. We are looking into the situation and will re-examine our current volunteer training. A positive museum experience for visitors of all ages is our utmost priority. Thank you so much for drawing this to our attention.    We hope you will visit us again. On June 21, we are opening our new Arctic Gallery (included in museum admission) which will offer genuine specimens, artifacts, multimedia and unique perspectives on this vast, mysterious and little-understood region.   Again, thank you, and please accept our apologies.”

Kieran - The whole story, and then some: ‘digital storytelling’ in evolving museum practice

My reflections

Nowadays, museums are having to face a lot of competition with technology. Museums entertain… Technology entertains… Museums are educational… Technology is educational… Museums are engaging… Technology is engaging… Moreover, storytelling is one of the main mandates of museums. Their collections exhibit stories related to arts, music, literature, science and etcetera. Nevertheless, technology can also be a powerful tool for storytelling; being even more interactive and adaptive to the individual. So… what could museums do to compete with technology? IF YOU CANNOT BEAT THEM – JOIN THEM. Museums are using technology, so the visitor is not only a passive observer, but also an active participant. In addition, Covid restrictions have caused people to explore virtual alternatives as well. For instance, the National Gallery of Canada is presenting online access to some of the Gallery’s Canadian, Indigenous and international collections. Plus, kids and adults can get creative with online activities.

Please have a look: https://www.gallery.ca/virtual-ngc https://www.gallery.ca/virtual-ngc#get-creative

By M Munoz

Jacob – The political rationality of the museum

My reflections

Are museums supposed to only entertain? Inspire? Educate? Or… Do museums have the political duty to change the world? For instance… During Trump’s Inauguration, the Queen’s Museum closed its doors in protest. Unfortunately, many museums only serve the purpose to keep collections from the ‘culture capital’ that belongs to elites only. Alternatively, the museum can become a way for the middle class to appreciate art, since they cannot buy art. Therefore, the museum might become a tool of inequality where everything is too white or too masculine. Many museums are managed by intolerant scholars who promote a political monoculture of the humanities. Thus, activists argue how museums should focus on groups that are traditionally neglected. Museums should promote social justice; they are not supposed to be condescending with their visitors.

By M Munoz

Week 5 Collaborative reading

Jenna – The origins of the public museum

My reflections

The real meaning of 'public' ...

Museum institutions should consider the participation of local communities when managing their collections; in this way, their projects have a higher chance of being culturally sensitive. When museums try to understand and adapt to the needs of local communities, a spirit of cooperation is developed among community members and stakeholders. Participatory mapping is another way for museums to promote culture inclusiveness. It gives the community a chance to express their perceptions and social constructions; and also to demonstrate what cultural/historic pieces they consider significant or not.

The origins of the public museum

chantalmb   2021-02-12 3:20 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I'd argue that without these variables, museum exhibits might end up pretty boring! As a small anecdote, in high school our history teacher took my gr. 12 history class to the CMH where after a tour of their temporary exhibit on Napoleon, we were given permission to freely explore the rest of the museum. So naturally, by the end of the day, we all ended up at the children's museum-- the most interactive section of the museum. While all exhibits allow you to "move" through history, the interactivity of being able to touch, visualize, and participate in history ultimately creates a much more rewarding experience!

I feel that well-planned exhibitions can and should risk whatever may result from adding interactive elements. Emotion cannot be avoided-- any type of exhibition has the risk of evoking emotion depending on the visitor's personal ties to the topic. Further, these emotions can be valuable by giving us another perspective on the topic at hand. Incorporating digital methods into an exhibit that gives the visitor a chance to explore history and the multi-faceted narratives within it through interaction, only risks giving the exhibit more value, in my opinion.
JacobSpierings   2021-02-08 12:27 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    
The capacities of digital media are such that they can simultaneously highlight multiple narratives, meaning linear narrative can be used without letting it wholly dictate a story experience.

Wong suggests that linear narrative provides cohesion and direction in storytelling. Liner narratives come with these qualities but they also can constrain users to a specific perspective. How digital media can unlock new ways for stories to be told, in both linear and non linear ways. What are the benefits and drawbacks with these to methods? chantalmb   2021-02-12 2:36 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

While I acknowledge the pitfalls of a linear narrative as both you and the article have addressed, I feel that linear narratives do have a place in museums as long as they are later contextualized; which, of course, is one of the benefits of digital storytelling! A basic example of this would be if a museum want to tell the story of something specific and relatively tangible, like a heritage building, as it change over time. This could be told linearly through something like a time lapse or along a timeline with accompanying text to explain the context which the object is situated during each phase of its life.

Linear narratives can become problematic when it comes to more multi-faceted events in history-- a good example of a topic that is often placed along a timeline when it probably shouldn't be is something like Civil War, where there are complex actors at play both before, during, and after. Wong highlights how linear narratives, can make these topics more digestible for the user, yet may result in an inaccurate or one-sided story, or a confusing story if it attempts to equally explain all sides of the story at once! I feel it's this in this case where digital methods of storytelling that give options on how to proceed as the narrative moves forward in time are best implemented. The history is still presented in that directed, linear form, but the user is engaged through opportunities to explore various elements of the narrative at each stage, at their own pace.
⤷
JacobSpierings   2021-02-12 4:10 p.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I agree that linear story lines do have a place in museums. I think this is one point that Wong was trying to make, that they are often more comprehensible to museum visitors. However there are advantages and disadvantage to using linear narratives and those often depend on the context. Digital and interactive exhibits also allow museums to present linear stories in new ways, such as having many different linear narratives on the same event that can be connected through digital means.

chantalmb   2021-02-12 4:20 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I think you're on to something here; despite increasing overlap as time progresses, the arts vs science mentality is still present, and as someone who has had the opportunity to engage in both "worlds", I found it interestingly (and frustratingly) more present in arts. There seems to be resistance against digitization in the archival and museum fields as it goes against "tradition" and requires new thought about the ethical issues that come with digitization as well as new practices to meet these new ways of disseminating information. You see this attitude trickle all the way down to the undergraduate level-- how many times have you heard one of your friends in the arts say something along the lines of "I don't do technology"? This is obviously said as a joke (mostly), but it does speak to this notion that someone who works within these fields of preserving things is meant to do just that as tradition dictates, rather than expanding this preservation into questions that could integrate the digital, such as, "by looking at the digital archive, how could all the data of these objects connect?"

In a cultural/historical sort of way, digital projects and innovation were broadly seen as unimportant, because they were secondary to what museums thought they ought to be providing: a physical space with tangible objects. I'm assuming COVID will act as a jolt to these beliefs as cultural institutions have no choice but to provide some form of online content to sustain themselves, but for this issue to truly be fixed, there needs to be a significant shift in belief about what these institutions are meant to provide and what they value, not shying away from technology but instead embracing it as their own and adapting it as a tool to deliver their message.

chantalmb   2021-02-12 3:52 a.m.   in 4916a-museums-dh    

I feel like this can bring us back to the first key takeaway of this survey too-- how many museums had little to no digital staff. By nature, digital humanities and the museum strategy that branches from it is interdisciplinary work. The app that @P.Wellz linked demonstrates this-- 3 different departments collaborated to create it!

Even with all of the tools made to be "easy to use", it is rare that a single person would be specialize in everything need for a digital project that is both user-friendly and well-written. It's also unlikely that the quality of a single person's digital work would be able to match the scale and caliber of work produced by someone who had even a few more team players with a diversified knowledge base in the same time frame. Museums don't need to necessarily have staff with a staff with knowledge of both the digital and humanistic (a rare combination to find tbh), but they at least need to create interdisciplinary teams so that things like virtual exhibits can meet their full potential through both containing accurate, curated knowledge, as well as visual stimulus and engagement that will draw virtual visitors in.
